How to Testify at the Maryland General Assembly

Testifying before the Maryland General Assembly is a powerful way to make your voice heard on important legislation. Whether you're advocating for election integrity or other issues, this guide will help you navigate the process with confidence.

Step-by-Step Guide to Testifying

  1. Find the Bill You Want to Testify On
    Visit mgaleg.maryland.gov to search for bills by number, keyword, or topic. Make note of the bill number and which committee will be hearing it.
  2. Check the Hearing Schedule
    Committee hearing schedules are posted on the General Assembly website. Hearings are typically scheduled a few days to a week in advance. Note the date, time, and location.
  3. Register to Testify
    You can register online through the Maryland General Assembly website or in person at the hearing. Online registration is strongly recommended as it allows committees to plan accordingly.
  4. Prepare Your Testimony
    Write out your key points. Keep your testimony concise (3-5 minutes). Focus on facts, personal experiences, and specific impacts of the legislation. Bring printed copies for committee members.
  5. Arrive Early
    Get to the hearing room at least 30 minutes early. Committee rooms can fill up quickly, especially for controversial bills. Check in with committee staff when you arrive.
  6. Deliver Your Testimony
    When called, state your name and who you represent (yourself or an organization). Speak clearly and stay within your time limit. Be respectful and factual. Legislators may ask questions‚Äîanswer honestly and concisely.
üí° Pro Tip: If you cannot attend in person, you can submit written testimony through the Maryland General Assembly website. While not as impactful as in-person testimony, it still gets your position on the record.

  • Clear recommendations ‚Äì Tell legislators what action you want them to take

Types of Testimony

Favorable Testimony

You support the bill and want it to pass. Explain why the legislation is beneficial and urge the committee to give it a favorable report.

Unfavorable Testimony

You oppose the bill and want it to be rejected. Clearly articulate the problems with the legislation and why it should not become law.

Favorable with Amendments

You support the concept but believe the bill needs changes. Suggest specific amendments that would make the bill better and more effective.

Informational Only

You provide facts or expertise without taking a position. This is less common but can be useful if you're an expert witness or representing a neutral organization.

‚è∞ Committee Hearing Times: Most committee hearings begin at 1:00 PM, but this can vary. Always verify the exact time on the General Assembly website. Sessions during the legislative session (January through April) are especially busy.

After You Testify

Your work doesn't end when you leave the hearing room. Follow these steps to maximize your impact:

  • Send a thank you email to committee members, especially those who asked you questions
  • Share your experience on social media to encourage others to get involved
  • Follow the bill's progress through the legislative process
  • Contact your own delegates and senators to ensure they know your position
  • If the bill advances, consider testifying again in the second chamber (House or Senate)
